block.p: Re your May 2 news article about the distribution of old cellular phones programmed to dial 911 to livery-cab drivers in New York City: I agree with those who tepidly applaud the gesture while questioning its usefulness. I cannot imagine carrying on a conversation with a 911 dispatcher while an assailant holds a gun to my head. Nor can I fathom an assailant who would allow his victim that ''one phone call.''

Re your May 2 news article about the distribution of old cellular phones programmed to dial 911 to livery-cab drivers in New York City: I agree with those who tepidly applaud the gesture while questioning its usefulness. I cannot imagine carrying on a conversation with a 911 dispatcher while an assailant holds a gun to my head. Nor can I fathom an assailant who would allow his victim that ''one phone call.''

Perhaps the Taxi and Limousine Commission could take a cue from the banking industry and consider a silent alarm system: after all, how many bank clerks pick up their cell phones and dial 911 during an armed robbery?
The police would not only be notified that there is an emergency but would also be able to track the signal emitted from the livery cab wherever it goes.
PETER KEMPE III New York, May 2, 2000
